utterance: Well,
speaker: Dame Toothacre

utterance: did I ever know such a spell of warm weather as we had the last fortnight?
speaker: Dame Toothacre

utterance: Yes,
speaker: Ma'am Trowbridge

utterance: it has fairly started the buds. Look, that pussy willow by the window is quite out.
speaker: Ma'am Trowbridge

utterance: My Mary says she has seen a liverwort blossom,
speaker: Dame Toothacre

utterance: and I 've heard bluebirds these two weeks, — it's a most uncommon season.
speaker: Dame Toothacre

utterance: If the warm weather holds on, Martha will have a good getting-up,
speaker: Dame Johnson

utterance: She's got as plump and likely a little girl as I should want to see.
speaker: Dame Johnson

utterance: Bless its heart !
speaker: Mother Fern

utterance: It's as downy as any of us.
speaker: Mother Fern

utterance: I should think it might be a young bluebird,
speaker: Mistress Liverwort

utterance: it looks as much like one as anything.
speaker: Mistress Liverwort

utterance: Come, what shall we give it?
speaker: Mistress Liverwort

utterance: I'll give it blue eyes, — real violet-blue, — and if that is n't a good gift, I don't know what is.
speaker: Mistress Liverwort

utterance: And I'll give her some of my thrift and prudence,
speaker: Mother Fern

utterance: Thrift will surely lead to riches and honor.
speaker: Mother Fern

utterance: I will give her a better thing than that,
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: I grow under the windows here, and mean to adopt her. She shall be called little Pussy Willow, and I shall give her the gift of always seeing the bright side of
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: We
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: D
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: everything. That gift will be more to her than beauty or riches or honors. It is not so much matter what color one's eyes are as what one sees with them. There is a bright side to everything, if people only knew it, and the best eyes are those which are able always to see this best side.
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: I must say, Friend Pussy,
speaker: Mother Fern

utterance: that you are a most sensibly spoken bush, for a bush of your age.
speaker: Mother Fern

utterance: You always did seem to me to have a most remarkable faculty in that line ; for I have remarked how you seize on the first ray of sunshine, and get your pussies out before any of us dare make a movement. Many a time I have said, 'Well, I guess Miss Pussy Willow 'll find herself mistaken in the weather this year'; but, taking one year with another, I think you have gained time by being always on hand, and believing in the pleasant weather.
speaker: Mother Fern

utterance: Well,
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: if I should hang back with my buds as our old Father Elm-tree does, I should miss a deal of pleasure, and people would miss a deal of pleasure from me.
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: The children, dear souls! I 'm always in a hurry to get out in the spring because it pleases them. 'O, here's Pussy Willow come back !'they cry when they see me.
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: Now the winter is over!'
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: And no matter if there is a little dash of sleet or snow or frost after that, I stand it with a good heart, because I know it is summer that is coming, and not winter, and that things are certain to grow better, and not worse.
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: I'm not handsome, I know; I'm not elegant; nobody thinks much of me; and my only good points are my cheerfulness and my faith in good things to come ; so these are the gifts I bring to my little god-child.
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: Was that a dog barking ?
speaker: Dame Toothacre

utterance: I thought I heard a dog.
speaker: Dame Toothacre

utterance: Good Night Dearie II.
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: WELL!
speaker: Nurse Toothacre

utterance: ELL!
speaker: Nurse Toothacre

utterance: said the old nurse, who would 'a' thought that 'ere baby would 'a' slept so ? — None o your worry-cats, she ain't.
speaker: Nurse Toothacre

utterance: I say, wife, what shall we call her?
speaker: John Primrose

utterance: she's a perfect March blossom, — come just as the pussy willows were out.
speaker: John Primrose

utterance: Let's call her Pussy Willow then,
speaker: Sam

utterance: May I get down and play now?
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: Wait a moment till I get my hands out of the bread.
speaker: mamma

utterance: No! no! naughty !
speaker: Martha Primrose

utterance: No! no!
speaker: Martha Primrose

utterance: Naughty !
speaker: Martha Primrose

utterance: No! no! naughty baby!
speaker: Martha Primrose

utterance: You can't put her out,
speaker: Martha Primrose

utterance: she's the best little thing; but it is wonderful the mischief she does. She just goes from one thing to another all day long.
speaker: Martha Primrose

utterance: She's got more laugh in her than a whole circus,
speaker: John Primrose

utterance: I don't want no theatre nor no opera when I can have her
speaker: John Primrose

utterance: Naughty baby!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: No! no!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: She is too sensitive for this life,
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: the sweet little angel!
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: Can you ?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: I really think you 'll have to harness and drive the old 27 > mare over to Aunt Judy's, and get her to come over.
speaker: Pussy's mother

utterance: That's a trouble. The hay is all ready to get in, and there will certainly be rain by afternoon. The horse cannot possibly be spared.
speaker: Pussy's father

utterance: Now, mother, just let me make bread. I've seen you do it, time and time again, and I know I could do it.
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: Hurrah for Pussy ! she's a trump. You let her try, — she 'll do it.
speaker: Pussy's brothers

utterance: Yes, yes. I'd rather have my little Pussy than a dozen Aunt Judys.
speaker: Pussy's father

utterance: Now scatter in a handful of salt.
speaker: Pussy's mother

utterance: Now make a little hole in the middle, and measure three gills of yeast, and put that in the hole.
speaker: Pussy's mother

utterance: And now for your wetting, Pussy. You want about a quart of hot water and a quart of good milk to begin with, and we'll see how you go on. But I'm a little afraid you 're not strong enough to knead such a big batch.
speaker: Pussy's mother

utterance: O mother, I'm a large girl now, and you've no idea how strong I am! I want to knead a real batch, just such as you do, and not a little play batch, — a baby's batch.
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: Well, well, we 'll try it. and I 'll pour in your wetting.
speaker: Pussy's mother

utterance: O mother, I like this ! — it's the best fun I ever had. How soft and smooth I am getting it! It's beginning to rise, I do believe, this very minute ; I can feel it rising under my hands. I shall be so proud to show it to father and the boys! Mother, you 'll always let me make the bread, won't you?
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: We'll see. Mind you knead in every bit of the flour. Don't leave any on the sides of the pan. 9) Rub all those ragged patches together, and knead them in. You are getting it quite smooth.
speaker: Pussy's mother

utterance: There now, Mrs. Bread, there you are. now I shall tuck you up warm and put you to sleep, till it's time to take you up and bake you.
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: And now, mother, shall I put on the dinner pot ?
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: Yes, you may put it on; and then you may go down cellar, and get a piece of beef and a piece of pork, and bring them up for dinner.
speaker: Pussy's mother

utterance: Now, Pussy, you can go and play down by the brook for an hour and a half.
speaker: Pussy's mother

utterance: Mother, I like working better than play.
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: It is play to you now, but if you had to do these things every day, you might get tired.
speaker: Pussy's mother

utterance: It was real lively yeast. I knew it would rise quickly.
speaker: Pussy's mother

utterance: Wife, you'll take your ease now, since you have such a little housekeeper sent to you.
speaker: Pussy's father

utterance: Mother, I'm going to ask God to keep me humble.
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: Why, my dear?
speaker: Pussy's mother

utterance: Because I feel tempted to be proud, — I can make such good bread!
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: So here you are, Mr. Robin. You and I are up early this I morning, ar' n't we? Ha, ha, old Mr. Chipmunk, — is that you? Take care of yourself, or I shall catch you. You are up getting breakfast for your family, and I for mine. Mother is sick, and I'm housekeeper now, Mr. Chip.
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: There's a girl for you! That girl does credit to our teaching. Every feeling of her heart is as fresh and clear as spring-water, and she goes on doing good just as the brook runs in a bright, merry stream. That girl will never know what it is to be nervous or low-spirited, or have the dyspepsia, or any of the other troubles that come on the lazy daughters of men. And it all comes of the gifts that we wood-fairies have brought her. She takes everything by the smooth handle, and sees everything on the bright side, and enjoys her work a great deal more than most children do their play.
speaker: Mother Fern

utterance: I've seen mother do this often enough, and I'll surprise her by getting it all nicely into the oven without her saying a word about it.
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: I do believe, mother, I do believe Pussy is up before you.
speaker: Pussy's father

utterance: Good child ! she is making the fire for With a little instruction she will be able to make a corncake nicely.
speaker: Pussy's mother

utterance: Mother! mother! sha' n't I come in and help you dress ?
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: Thank you, dear child ; I was just thinking of coming to call you. I wanted you to make the fire for me.
speaker: Pussy's mother

utterance: It's made, mother, - long ago.
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: What a good girl! Well then, you may just get a pail of water and fill the tea-kettle.
speaker: Pussy's mother

utterance: I got the water and filled the kettle half an hour ago, mother, and you can't think how it's boiling! — puffing away like a steamboat, -and. I've put the coffee on to boil, and
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: You have been a very good girl. You are such a nice handy little housekeeper that I think I can easily show you how to get the whole breakfast. Would n't you like to have me teach you how to mix the corn-cakes !
speaker: Pussy's mother

utterance: So, she's got it done at last, – that hateful Madame Tulleruche! She always keeps me waiting so long that I 39 am tired to death. But there !- she has But there ! — she has gone and put that trimming on in folds, and I told her I wanted puffs. The dress is just ruined. Take it away, Bridget. I can't bear the sight of it. I do wonder what is the reason that I never can have anything done as other girls can. There's always something the matter with my things.
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: Troth, Miss Emily, it's jist that ye's got too much of ivrything, and your stomach is kept turned all the time. If ye had to work as I do for your new dresses, ye'd like 'em better, that's what ye would. I tell ye what would do ye more good than all the fine things ye 's got, and that same 's a continted mind.
speaker: Bridget

utterance: But how can I be contented, when nothing ever suits me? I'm so particular, — mamma says so. I'm so, , and I can't help it, and nobody ever does do anything quite as I like it; and so I am unhappy all the time.
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: And what if ye did something for somebody else, instead of having everybody else a-serving ye? I works from morning to night, and gets my two dollars a week, and sends the most part of it to me poor old mother in Ireland ; and it keeps me jolly — praise be to God !— to think I'm a-comfortin' her old age. Did ye ever think whether ye did anything for anybody?
speaker: Bridget

utterance: What a blessing our little Pussy has been to us!
speaker: Pussy's father

utterance: Yes, that dear child is so unselfish, and so much more than willing to do for us, that I am fearful lest we shall make too much of her. I don't want to make a mere drudge of my daughter, and I think we must send her to school this summer. Pussy is a good reader, — I have always taught her a little every day, -and she writes little letters on a slate quite prettily for a child ; but now I think we must send her over to the Academy, and let her go in with the primary class.
speaker: Pussy's mother

utterance: Please don't tell me a word. I want to work it out myself, I'm sure I can do it.
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: Now, my dear, you ought not to do it. You ought to have Saturday to amuse yourself.
speaker: Pussy's mother

utterance: Well, it amuses me to make the pies. I like to see how many I can turn out in a day. I don't ask better fun.
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: I wait till spring? What for? What do I care for cold and snow ? I like them: I'm a real snow-bird, — my blood races and bounds so in cold weather that I like nothing better than being out. As to th
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: "Wife, our Pussy is growing into a real handsome little woman."
speaker: John Primrose

utterance: “ Am I pretty, I wonder ?"
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: "She is pretty,"
speaker: Mother Fern

utterance: "She is pretty, and she has come now to the time when she may as well know it. She will begin now to dress herself, and brush out her feathers, as the bluebirds and robins do in the spring-time."
speaker: Mother Fern

utterance: "Why, how now? You look as your mother used to when I went a-courtin'. Girls always get the knack of fixin' up when their time comes.”
speaker: John Primrose

utterance: "I say, wife, you must get Pussy a new bonnet."
speaker: John Primrose

utterance: "I've been braiding the straw for one all winter. Last fall we picked and sorted the straw, and got the very nicest, and I have enough now done to make a nice straw hat. I will soon have it sewed, and then, when you drive over to Elverton, you can get it pressed in Josiah's bonnet factory."
speaker: Martha Primrose

utterance: "And I'll buy her a ribbon myself,"
speaker: John Primrose

utterance: "No, no, father; after all, it would be better to let me have the wagon and the old horse, and take her over to Worcester to choose for herself. Girls have their own notions."
speaker: Martha Primrose

utterance: "Well, perhaps that 'ere's the best way, mother. I tell you what, that child has been a treasure to us, and I would n't stand for expense; get her a new gown too. I won't stand If you have to spend ten dollars, I would n't mind it, to have her dressed up as handsome as any gal that sits in the singers' seats on Sunday."
speaker: John Primrose

utterance: “ Why, father, what is this?"
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: "Well, I noticed last night how pretty you looked with your posies on, and I told your mother the time was come when you'd be a-wantin' folderols and such like, -as girls ought to a have when they come to the right age; and, as you've been always a good daughter, and never thought of yourself, why, we must think for you; and so there 't is. Get yourself any bit of finery you want with it. I don't grudge it."
speaker: John Primrose

utterance: "Let her have her way, child,"
speaker: John Primrose

utterance: "Don't you see that you are herself over again ? She has her young days again in dressing you."
speaker: John Primrose

utterance: "Mother! mother!"
speaker: John Primrose

utterance: "What is it, father?"
speaker: Martha Primrose

utterance: "But, mother,"
speaker: John Primrose

utterance: "is n't she the prettiest girl you ever saw ?"
speaker: John Primrose

utterance: "Father, dear, don't talk now."
speaker: Martha Primrose

utterance: "I declare, I don't grudge that 'ere ten dollars one grain."
speaker: John Primrose

utterance: "It is her sensitive nature that wears upon her,"
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: "She was never made for this world; she has an exquisiteness of perception which makes her feel even the creases in a rose-leaf.”
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: "Stuff and folderol, my dear madam!"
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: "Hum!-a fashionable potato-sprout !- grown in a cellar !- not a drop of red blood in her veins !"
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: "What odd ways he has, to be sure !"
speaker: Emily's grandmamma

utterance: "but then it's the way he talks to everybody."
speaker: Emily's grandmamma

utterance: "My dear madam, you have tried to make a girl out of loaf-sugar and almond paste, and now you are distressed that she has not red blood in her veins, that her lungs gasp and flutter when she goes up stairs. Turn her out to grass, my dear madam ; send her to old Mother Nature to nurse; stop her parties and her dancing and her music, and take off the corsets and strings round her lungs, and send her somewhere to a good honest farm-house in the hills, and let her run barefoot in the morning dew, drink new milk from the cow, romp in a good wide barn, learn to hunt hens' eggs, I'll warrant me you 'll see another pair of cheeks in a year. Medicine won't do her any good ; you may a make an apothecary's shop of her stomach, and matters will be only the worse. Why, there is n't iron enough in her blood to make a cambric needle !"
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: "Iron in her blood ! I never heard the like."
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: "Yes, iron, — red particles, globules, or whatever you please to call them. Her blood is all water and lymph, and that is why her cheeks and lips look so like a cambric handkerchief, — why she pants and puffs if she goes up stairs. Her heart is well enough, if there were only blood to work in it; but it sucks and wheezes like a dry pump for want of vital fluid. She must have more blood, madam, and nature must make it for her."
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: "We were thinking of going to Newport, Doctor."
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: "Yes, to Newport, to a ball every night, and a flurry of dressing and firtation every morning. No such thing! Send her to a lonesome, unfashionable old farm-house, where there was never a more exciting party than a quilting-frolic heard of. Let her learn the difference between huckleberries and blackberries, – learn where checkerberries grow thickest, and dig up sweet-flag-root with her own hands, as country children do. It would do her good to plant a few hills of potatoes, and hoe them herself, as I once heard of a royal princess doing, because queens can afford to be sensible in bringing up their daughters."
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: "Indeed, we have never done such a thing, or thought of it. I don't know what to say till I ask my husband."
speaker: Martha Primrose

utterance: "My daughter is a great invalid, and the Doctor has recommended country air for her."
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: "I'm afraid it would be too dull here to suit her,"
speaker: Martha Primrose

utterance: "That is the very thing the Doctor requires. My daughter's nerves are too excitable, — she requires perfect quiet and repose."
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: "What is the matter with your daughter ?"
speaker: Martha Primrose

utterance: "Well, she is extremely delicate; she suffers from palpitations of the heart; she can't go up stairs, even, or make the smallest exertion, without bringing on dreadful turns of fluttering and faintness."
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: "I'm afraid we should not be able to wait on her as she would need. We keep no servants."
speaker: Martha Primrose

utterance: "We would be willing to pay well for it. Money is no object with us."
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: "Mother, do let her come. I want her to get well, and I'll wait on her. I'm never tired, and could do twice as much as I do any day."
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: "What a healthy-looking daughter you have !"
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: "Well, if she thinks best, I think we will try to do it; for about everything on our place goes as she says, and she has the care of everything."
speaker: Martha Primrose

utterance: "Do pray, dear Dr. Hardhack, tell us just how she must be dressed for that cold mountain region. Must she have highnecked, long-sleeved flannels?"
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: "I will make her half a dozen at once,"
speaker: Aunt Maria

utterance: "Not so fast. Let's see about this young lady,"
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: "I thought so. I supposed that there was n't much breathing room allowed behind there."
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: "O, I do assure you, Doctor, Emily never dresses tight,"
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: "No indeed ! I despise tight lacing. I never wear my clothes any more than just comfortable.”
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: "Never saw a woman that did. The courage and constancy of the female sex in bearing inconveniences is so great, however, that that will be no test at all. Why, if you should catch a fellow, and gird his ribs in as Miss Emily wears hers all the time, he'd roar like a bull of Bashan. You would n't catch a man saying he felt 'comfortable' under such circumstances; but only persuade a girl that she looks stylish and fashionable with her waist drawn in, and you may screw and screw till the very life leaves her, and with her dying breath she will tell you that it is nothing more than 'com< fortable.' So, my young lady, you don't catch me in that way. You must leave off belts and tight waists of all sorts for six months at least, and wear only loose sacks, or thingumbobs, – whatever you call 'em, — so that your lungs may have some chance to play, and fill with the vital air I'm going to send you to breathe up in the hills."
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: "But, Doctor, I don't believe I could hold myself up without corsets. When I sit up in a loose dress, I feel so weak I hardly know what to do. I need the support of something around me."
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: Is n't Dr. Hardhack so original ?
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: But then, you know, he's all the fashion now.
speaker: Emily's grandmamma

utterance: Why, Dr. Hardhack, I don't see as we shall ever get our Emily home again. I keep writing and writing, and still she says she is n't ready ; there is always something ahead.
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: Let her alone, ma'am, let her alone.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: Give Nature a chance more; you 'll all be tumbling on to her, and trying to undo all the good she's getting, as soon as you get her home; so let her stay as long as possible.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: O Dr. Hardback, you are so queer !
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: Truth, ma'am !
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: You are perfectly longing to kill that child ; it's all you can do to allow her a chance to breathe. But I insist upon it that she shall keep away from you as long as she has a mind to.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: Did you ever see such a queer old dear as Dr. Hardhack?
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: He does say the oddest things !
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: WELL now, Dr. Hardhack, does n't our Emily look beautifully?
speaker: Emily's mother and Emily's grandmamma and Aunt Zarviah

utterance: Pretty fair!
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: pretty fair! A tolerable summer's work, that!
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: Firm fibre, that! real hard flesh, made of clover and morning dew, — none of your flabby, sidewalk, skinny construction.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: Well now, Doctor, we want you to tell us just what she may do, — just how much. I suppose you know, now she's got into a city, she can't dress exactly as she did up in the country.
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: I see, I see.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: I take at once.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: You see, there is n't a thing of all her clothes that she can wear, having been all summer in those loose sacks, you know. She's sort o' spread out, you > see.
speaker: Aunt Zarviah

utterance: I should think so.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: Well, my advice is, that you begin gradually screwing her up; get her corsets ready, with plenty of whalebone and a good tough lace; but don't begin too hard, — just tighten a little every day, and by and by she'll get back to where all her things will fit her exactly.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: But, Doctor, won't that injure her health ?
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: Of course it will, but I fancy she 'll stand it for one winter; it won't quite kill her, and that's all we doctors want.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: If it suits you all, it does me, I'm sure. What should I do for my bread and butter, if all the girls of good families kept on living as these two have been living this summer? I really could n't afford it, in a professional point of view.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: Well, I have something to say on this point.
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: I would n't lose my health again for anything that can be named.
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: O pooh, pooh! I've heard a deal of talk of this sort before now.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: When the Devil was sick, the Devil a monk would be, When the Devil got well, the devil a monk was he.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: Thank you, Doctor.
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: but I think that poetry does n't apply to me, if you please. I hope I'm not of that family.
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: Well, — but seriously, Doctor, you must tell us just how much it will do for Emily to do.
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: One does n't want to give up the world entirely, and yet one does n't want to lose one's health.
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: I see.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: I appreciate the case entirely. Well, let her begin with the opera twice a week, and one German, kept up till daylight. In one week she will feel stronger than ever she did, and declare that nothing hurts her; then she can take two Germans, and then three, and so on. Fact is, of all the devices of modern society, none is so good for the medical practice as these Germans; my best cases are made out of 'em; they unite all the requisites for forming first-rate patients that keep on our hands for months and years, and are as good as an annuity to us. I'm not a fool, madam. I must look ahead for my bread and butter next spring, you see.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: But, Doctor, I'm not going to Germans at all.
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: I know now what life is, and what health is worth, and I'm not going to waste it in that way. Besides, I'm going to try to live for something better.
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: Live for something better !
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: What sort of talk is that for a young lady in the first New York society? What is there to live for better? I thought of it the other night when I was at a confirmation at Grace Church, and saw a whole bevy of pretty creatures, who all were engaging to 'fight manfully under Christ's banner,' and thought where they would be before spring. Whirling round all night in a low-necked dress is the kind of fighting they do; and then I'm called in as hospital surgeon to the dear disciples when they are carried off the field exhausted. I know all about it. You can't, of course, live for anything better. You could n't, for the world, be called singular, and be thought to have odd notions, — could you? That would be too horrible.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: Now I knew a rich New York girl once who took to bad courses. She would go round visiting the poor, she would sit up with sick people, and there was no end to the remarks made about her. People clearly saw how wicked it was of her to risk her health in that way,—how late hours and bad air and fatigue would certainly undermine her health, — and she was quite cast out of the synagogue. You must n't breathe bad air or over-exert yourself, unless you do so from a purely selfish motive; then it's all right and proper, — this is our New York gospel.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: O, you need n't sit there looking mischievous, miss. What do you know of life? You're nothing but a country girl, and you know no more of it than the bobolinks and chipsquirrels do. You'll soon learn to be ashamed of your roses, and to think it's pretty to have bad health. I'll bet a copper that you'll begin a course of corsets in a fortnight, and by spring we shall send you back to your milk-pails as white and withered as Miss Emily there. It's astonishing how fast we can run a girl down, taking one thing with another, the corsets, and the hot rooms with plenty of gas escaping into them from leaky tubes, and then operas and Germans for every night in the week. Of course it's a charity to give you a good stiff dose of it; it's hospitality, you see
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: Now, Doctor Hardhack, you dreadful man, you must just stop this talk, I brought Pussy down here on purpose to have somebody to help me to live better than I have lived. We shall just take a peep or two at New York sights, but we are not going into the gay world.
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: Ta, ta, ta ! don't tell me.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: you won't be so unfair as to cut me in that way. I shall hear of you yet, — you 'll see
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: What a droll man he is !
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: It's just his way, he's always running on in this strange way about everything. For my part, I never know half what he means.
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: It is tolerably plain what he means.
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: You must do exactly contrary to what he tells you, -- as I shall ; so, aunty, don't trouble yourself to try to alter my things, unless it be to let them all out, for I'm going to keep all the breathing-room I've got, whether I have a pretty waist or not. I'd rather have color in my cheeks, and a cheerful heart, than the smallest waist that ever was squeezed together.
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: Such a pity one could n't have both !.
speaker: Aunt Zarviah

utterance: Your cousin Jane was in here last week with her new bismarck silk, and it fits her so beautifully! Somebody said she looked as if she'd been melted and poured into it; there was n't a crease or a wrinkle! It did look lovely!
speaker: Aunt Zarviah

utterance: Well, Aunt Zarviah, I must try some other way of looking lovely. Maybe, if I am always gay and happy, and in good spirits, and have a fresh bright face, it may make up for not looking as if I had been melted and poured into my clothes.
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: Now,
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: I am not going to give my class just the odds and ends and parings of strength which I have left after I have spent almost all in amusing myself; but I mean to do just the other way, and spend the strength left from really useful things in amusing myself.
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: What is to become of me if you go on so ?
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: It's a conspiracy against our bread and butter, the way these girls go on.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: I sha'n't have a shadow of a case in Miss Emily, and I'm an abused man.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: Nobody knows whether we shall ever see George again.
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: O, why was I not a man? Why could I not go with him?
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: I am sick of all these things.
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: I never knew before what a brave boy our George was.
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: Do you know he told me that he was going to be in the thickest of all the fighting, and volunteer to go into every danger. Is n't it splendid of him?
speaker: Emily Proudie

utterance: Yes, indeed it is.
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: I know my brothers have enlisted. Here is the letter mother writes about them. Three of them gone in one regiment, and only one left to help father! He wanted to go, but they felt it was the duty of one to stay, and so he stayed !
speaker: Pussy Willow

utterance: Are n't you afraid, Doctor, that Emily will wear herself out with visiting the hospitals and working for the soldiers ?
speaker: Emily's mother

utterance: I think she 'll stand it, rather better than she used to stand the opera and the German some winters ago.
speaker: Dr. Hardhack

utterance: And if I don't, I'd rather wear out than rust out. I have found out what life is good for now.
speaker: Emily Proudie
